Topic: Draw reversible and irreversible changes (ice melting vs. egg cooking)
CAN: The student can draw the original state of the material before heating or cooling, such as solid ice and a raw egg.
The student can partially depict the material after it has been heated or cooled, like melted water or a cooked egg, though with some inaccuracies.
The student can attempt to show the concept of reversibility with a drawing of water turning back into ice, albeit with incomplete or unclear steps.
CANNOT: The student struggles to accurately represent the irreversible change, such as not clearly showing that a cooked egg cannot return to a raw state *(student thinks all changes can be reversed)*.
The student may incorrectly label or fail to label changes as reversible or irreversible *(missing labels or misunderstood concept)*.
The student shows minimal understanding of the cause and effect relationships in their drawing (e.g., missing arrows or connections between heating/cooling and change).
